review.title: Quantifying Natural and Artificial Intelligence in Robots and Natural Systems with an Algorithmic Behavioural Test
review.abstract: One of the most important aims of the fields of robotics, artificial intelligence and artificial life is the design and construction of systems and machines as versatile and as reliable as living organisms at performing high level human-like tasks. But how are we to evaluate artificial systems if we are not certain how to measure these capabilities in living systems, let alone how to define life or intelligence? Here I survey a concrete metric towards measuring abstract properties of natural and artificial systems, such as the ability to react to the environment and to control one's own behaviour.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: We have seen how similarly natural and artificial machines and systems can be evaluated with a concept of behavioral programmability, objectively and quantitatively and subjectively in relation to this latter property in accordance with some desirable characteristics for evaluation, such as how intelligent a system is in relation to another or in relation to a specific expectation.The unit of measurement has been applied here to the conception and control of self-organized molecular computers using porphyrins [15] and in psychology to subjective random quantification [7].The family of measures based on algorithmic complexity introduced and studied here is behavioral and in the spirit similar to the Turing Test for Machine Intelligence, but broadened in a precise manner, quantifying the response sensitivity of a system to external stimuli from the perspective of the observer.
